source_scope.notes: Non-alarmist civic, economy, community, and practical weather updates. Prioritize items published in the last 24 hours; include recent municipal updates when local publishing is sparse.

articles.title: Flood Watch with rounds of heavy rain: practical impacts for Morgan County travel through Saturday

sources.publisher: National Weather Service Huntsville (HUN) — Area Forecast Discussion

summary: A Flood Watch is in effect across the Tennessee Valley as multiple waves of rain and embedded storms move through Friday into Saturday morning/noon.
Expected totals are generally in the 1.5–3 inch range, with localized higher amounts possible; the main practical risk is ponding and brief flash-flood issues in low spots and poor drainage areas.
Best near-term watch item: timing of the heavier bands relative to the Friday commute and overnight period into Saturday.
articles.body_markdown:
## What happened
Forecast updates early Friday flagged multiple rounds of heavy rainfall for the Tennessee Valley, with a Flood Watch in place into Saturday and periodic storms capable of producing brief high rain rates.

## Why it matters
For Decatur, Priceville, and Hartselle, the most likely day-to-day impact is road conditions: ponding on busy routes, slower commutes, and occasional short-notice detours where drainage is weak.

## What to watch
Pay attention to the timing of the heaviest rain bands (especially overnight into Saturday morning) and any localized flood advisories if rainfall rates spike in your immediate area.

articles.title: Festival of the Cranes returns to Decatur for the peak migration weekend
summary: Decatur’s annual Festival of the Cranes is back for 2026, centered on the second weekend of January when viewing tends to be strongest.
The core viewing area is around Wheeler National Wildlife Refuge, with related activities extending into downtown Decatur.
Weather may affect outdoor viewing comfort, but organizers noted many activities are indoors and the refuge is open rain or shine.
articles.body_markdown:
## What happened
Local coverage outlined the return of Decatur’s Festival of the Cranes, timed to the seasonal peak for large bird concentrations at Wheeler National Wildlife Refuge.

## Why it matters
This is one of the region’s repeatable winter draws: it’s a practical indicator of weekend visitor traffic for downtown businesses and a predictable community activity window.

## What to watch
If you’re planning to go, watch the hourly rain bands for the best viewing windows and expect heavier-than-normal weekend activity around refuge access points and downtown event venues.

articles.title: Decatur completes Flying Dragon disc golf renovations with grant-supported upgrades
summary: The City of Decatur reported completion of renovations at the Flying Dragon Disc Golf Course at Jack Allen Recreation Complex, focused on safety, navigation, and playability.
Work included new concrete tee pads, refurbished targets, updated signage, improved walkways, and removal of hazards on holes 11–18.
The city reported a total project cost of $114,312, including a $100,000 grant and local match funding.
articles.body_markdown:
## What happened
Decatur announced the completion of a renovation package for the Flying Dragon Disc Golf Course, targeting specific holes and on-course wayfinding/safety improvements.

## Why it matters
Small, targeted recreation upgrades tend to have outsized community value: they improve everyday usability, reduce maintenance friction, and can support local tournaments and visitor traffic without major new construction.

## What to watch
If usage increases, the next watch item is whether the city schedules additional improvements at other disc golf locations or expands event programming tied to these amenities.

articles.title: Hartselle reminds local businesses: annual license renewals due; delinquent starting February 1
summary: The City of Hartselle posted a reminder that business (privilege) licenses renew annually and are due January 1 each year.
The notice states licenses become delinquent as of February 1 and that renewal forms were mailed to existing businesses, with options to request forms via email or in person.
The city also notes related renewal timelines for alcohol licenses and mobile food unit licensing/permits.
articles.body_markdown:
## What happened
Hartselle issued a routine compliance reminder for annual business license renewals and related permitting timelines.

## Why it matters
For local operators, these reminders reduce avoidable penalties and administrative friction. For the city, predictable licensing cycles support planning and service delivery without drama.

## What to watch
Watch for any follow-on updates about inspections (especially for mobile food units) and whether the city publishes additional guidance for new businesses opening in 2026.

articles.title: Decatur backs effort to change online sales tax distribution; Priceville declines participation
summary: A report on Alabama’s simplified seller’s use tax (SSUT) dispute described Decatur’s decision to back a statewide lawsuit challenging distribution rules for online sales tax revenue.
The same report notes some smaller cities, including Priceville, voted to decline participation in the effort.
Decatur officials in the report estimate substantial revenue loss under the current distribution approach, framing the issue as a long-run municipal finance and infrastructure question.
articles.body_markdown:
## What happened
Coverage summarized differing municipal positions on SSUT distribution: Decatur voted to back a lawsuit challenging the framework, while Priceville declined to join.

## Why it matters
Online sales tax distribution is a quiet but meaningful lever for local budgets. When rules shift who receives revenue, downstream impacts often show up as slower project timelines, deferred maintenance, or fewer discretionary upgrades.

## What to watch
Watch for whether the lawsuit changes distribution formulas, how quickly any changes would phase in, and whether cities adjust capital plans or bond assumptions based on the outcome.
